questions.text: Anti-retroviral therapy in HIV-infected individuals should be initiated at _______

choices.text: CD4 count <200 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 2/3
CD4 count <350 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 3/4
CD4 count <250 cells/ul and/or WHO clinical stage 4
Any CD4 count regardless of WHO clinical stage

questions.solution:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is recommended for all HIV patients, regardless of CD4 T lymphocyte cell count or clinical stage.

This is done to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with HIV infection. A secondary goal of ART is to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

Islatravir, the first nucleoside reverse transcriptase translocation inhibitor (NRTTI), along with Doravirine the recently approved non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) may offer a potent and well-tolerated two-drug regimen for HIV maintenance therapy, according to a recent study.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fourth-generation serological testing for HIV?

choices.text: It is used to confirm the diagnosis of HIV
It detects HIV antibodies and antigen
It has a lower sensitivity compared to first-generation HIV testing
It cannot be used to detect HIV-2 antibodies

questions.solution:
The 4th generation HIV test combines the detection of antibodies against HIV-1 & HIV-2 with detection of the core p24 antigen of HIV-1. Inclusion of p24 antigen capture allows detection of HIV-1 infection even before seroconversion i.e., presence of antibodies in the blood.

The approximate time to positivity following infection is 15 to 20 days. Consequently, the window period between infection and detection of the infection is shortened.

Fourth-generation HIV testing is highly sensitive (99.9%) and is the CDC-recommended initial screening test for HIV. No further testing is required for specimens that are non-reactive on ELISA screening.

Generation Serological test
First generation IgG antibody
Second generation IgG antibody
Third generation IgM and IgG antibody
Fourth generation IgM and IgG antibody and p24 antigen

questions.text: A 46-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with acute dull and boring abdominal pain. His history is significant for ongoing treatment with ART. Serum lipase levels were noted to be grossly elevated. What is the most likely causative drug?
questions.solution:
Didanosine is the most likely causative drug. The clinical scenario, suggestive of pancreatitis, is a dose-limiting side effect of didanosine and occurs more frequently in alcoholic patients and those with hypertriglyceridemia.

Option A: Nevirapine side-effects include severe liver problems, skin rash, and skin reactions. 

Option C: Emtricitabine is contraindicated in pregnancy and young children.

Option D: Stavudine can cause peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient is upset because he has a high viral load despite good compliance with ART. The physician decides to start him on a parenteral drug. Which of the following drugs will be helpful for this patient?
questions.solution:
Enfuvirtide is the antiretroviral drug administered parenterally, used only in the treatment of those who have evidence of HIV replication i.e., high viral load, despite ongoing antiretroviral therapy. 

Enfuvirtide prevents viral fusion and entry by binding to the gp41 subunit of the HIV-1 envelope. It is not active against HIV-2. It is administered as a twice-a-day subcutaneous injection.

Note: Zidovudine is also available as a parenteral formulation.

The FDA has recently approved a combination of cabotegravir and rilpivirine as a complete regimen for HIV-1 infected adults. It was introduced to replace the current regimen in those who are virologically suppressed on a stable antiretroviral regimen with no history of treatment failure. This is the first FDA-approved injectable regimen for HIV-1 infected adults.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute infection with hepatitis B virus. The preferred regimen in the management of HIV-1 and hepatitis B co-infection is tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir. 

This regimen is also the first-line management in adults, adolescents, pregnant women, and HIV-TB co-infection. 

Antivirals that are effective against hepatitis C infection are sofosbuvir, grazoprevir and glecaprevir.

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is not used in HIV & hepatitis B co-infection?
questions.solution:
Abacavir is not used in HIV and hepatitis-B co-infection. It is used in the first-line ART regimen for patients with abnormal serum creatinine values.

Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) drugs like lamivudine, its closely related drug emtricitabine, and the nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) tenofovir have activity against hepatitis B virus. These drugs are preferred in combination with other antiretrovirals for the treatment of HIV & HBV co-infections.

questions.text: Screening of patients for HLA- B5701 is recommended before initiation of which of the following antiretroviral drugs?
questions.solution:
Screening of patients for HLA-B5701 is recommended before initiation of abacavir since it is associated with hypersensitivity.

The hypersensitivity syndrome includes fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal problems, malaise and fatigue. Hence, abacavir should only be used as a last resort and with close monitoring in patients who are HLA-B5701-positive.

questions.text: Evaluation of a patient with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension has revealed moderately increased albuminuria. He has recently been diagnosed with HIV infection. Combination ART preparations including which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenerio is suggestive of early stages of diabetic and hypertensive kidney disease. So combinaton antiretroviral therapy (cART) preparations including tenfovir should not be prescribed to this patient.

Tenofovir is primarily eliminated by the kidneys and is contraindicated in patients with renal impairment.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man on cART is presented with the following finding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat redistribution resulting in the classic buffalo hump appearance. Nelfinavir is the most likely cause.

It is a protease inhibitor and its chronic administration can result in fat redistribution and metabolic syndrome. 

Note: Atazanavir has the least propensity to cause lipodystrophy and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 54-year-old HIV-positive woman has a Hb of 8gm/dl. Combination ART preparations including which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution: Zidovudine should be avoided in this patient because the primary toxicity of zidovudine is bone marrow suppression. It can lead to anemia and neutropenia, which may require transfusions.

questions.text: During his routine counselling, a war veteran on cART for the past 2 weeks tells his therapist that he wishes to discontinue his HIV treatment. He explains that since starting them, he has been having extreme dizziness and intense nightmares leading to repeated wakening in the night. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely prescribed a cART regimen including efavirenz.

Many patients treated with efavirenz note a feeling of light-headedness and dizziness following the initiation of therapy. They also complain of insomnia, vivid dreams and nightmares.

These symptoms are self-limiting and tend to disappear gradually after several weeks of therapy. If the sleep problems are persistent, stopping the drug is the only solution.

It is recommended to take efavirenz before bedtime to minimize side effects.

The CNS/ psychiatric adverse effects seen with the use of efavirenz are:

  • Frank psychosis (depression, hallucinations, and/or mania) 
  • Impaired concentration
  • Dysphoria 
  • Dizziness
  • Vivid dreams
  • Insomnia

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man is tested for HIV and the following band pattern is seen on a standard western blot. Protein gp36 is present on the immunoblotting assay. To which class of antiretroviral drug would he be intrinsically resistant?
Env (gp160, gp120,gp41)  Negative
Gag (p55, p24, p17)  Positive
Pol (p66, p51, p32)  Positive
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of HIV-2 infection. It is intrinsically resistant to non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) and also to fusion inhibitor enfuvirtide. 

Western blot has a high specificity. It detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env. 

Persons with HIV-2 will often have an indeterminate western blot pattern showing the presence of Gag bands and Pol bands, but an absence of Env bands. This pattern occurs because HIV-1 and HIV-2 share little similarity in the env gene. Moreover, the presence of gp36 points towards a diagnosis of HIV-2.

In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests.

questions.text: An individual positive for HIV-1 infection was started on a combination ART regimen of tenofovir–emtricitabine–efavirenz. After 6 months, failure of treatment was established and attributed to efavirenz resistance. Which drug of the same class can be used instead?
questions.solution:
Etravirine can be used instead of efavirenz.

Etravirine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) currently approved for the treatment of HIV infection in combination with other agents in treatment-experienced patients.

Options A, B: Etravirine is active against strains of HIV that are resistant to other NNRTIs such as delavirdine, nevirapine, and efavirenz which all exhibit cross-resistance. Rilpivirine, an NNRTI, is also effective across a broad range of NNRTI-resistant viruses but shares cross-resistance with etravirine.

Option C: Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor and hence, does not belong to the same class.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

However, in patients with CD4 <50/μL, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore ART should be started as early as possible.

Note: As per RNTCP guidelines, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.

World HIV day is observed annually on 1st December. This year’s theme is “Putting Ourselves to the Test: Achieving Equity to End HIV.” It encourages people to unite globally to eliminate the disparities and inequities that create barriers to HIV testing, prevention, and access to HIV care

For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother?
questions.solution:
In a baby born to an HIV-infected mother, HIV infection is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR. NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18 months for Early Infant Diagnosis (EID).

Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally acquired maternal antibodies. For this reason, HIV virologic testing must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA to diagnose HIV infection in children.

Scheduled repeated testing is necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure and very recent infection will not be detectable. The cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the sample with maternal blood.

questions.text: A 29-year-old HIV-positive woman presents to the OPD with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnostic test for this condition in this patient?

choices.text: Cartridge based nucleic acid amiplification test

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberculosis. Cartridge-based nucleic acid amiplification test (CBNAAT) is the diagnostic test for TB in HIV positive patients. 

CBNAAT is a rapid molecular test that detects the DNA of TB bacteria in HIV-positive individuals. It uses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens). It can give a result in less than 2 hours. It can also detect the genetic mutations associated with resistance to the drug rifampicin. 

Sputum microscopy has poor sensitivity for detecting TB in HIV-infected individuals due to fewer organisms in sputum.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was admitted for multiple episodes of seizures following 7 months of neurocognitive decline. He also had weight loss, paranoia, and delusions. Clinical workup revealed HIV infection along with the following findings on MRI. What is the ideal timing of steroid therapy in this condition?

choices.text: Just before obtaining the sample for a biopsy
There is no specific ideal timing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL). In this condition, glucocorticoids should be administered only after a biopsy has been obtained. This is because steroids have a cytolytic effect on lymphoma cells and hence may lead to nondiagnostic tissue.  

On CT, PCNSL is identified as a hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass. On MRI, vivid homogeneous enhancement, as well as restricted diffusion, is seen. 

PCNSL is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The workup usually includes:

  • HIV testing
  • CSF analysis
  • MRI spine 
  • PET/CT to assess the extent of the disease
  • Bone marrow biopsy

World AIDS Vaccine Day, also known as HIV Vaccine Awareness Day, is observed annually on May 18. HIV vaccine advocates mark the day by promoting the continued urgent need for a vaccine to prevent HIV infection and AIDS.

questions.text: What is the WHO recommendation regarding the initiation of cotrimoxazole prophylaxis?

choices.text: Any CD4 count or WHO clinical stage

questions.solution:
WHO recommends cotrimoxazole prophylaxis at CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4.

Only in settings where malaria or severe bacterial infections are highly prevalent, co-trimoxazole prophylaxis should be initiated regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 counts.

questions.text: A cachexic man presented with a non-productive cough and shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with HIV 6 months ago but is non-adherent to ART. Serum LDH is 350 U/L. Giemsa-stained smears are seen below. At what CD4 count should the prophylaxis be started according to the CDC recommendation to prevent this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The prophylaxis for PCP is started at <200/mm3 CD4 count according to the CDC recommendation. In PCP LDH is elevated and smear stained with Giemsa stain shows trophic forms with dot-like nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm as well as intracystic bodies of Pneumocystis jiroveci.

Primary prophylaxis of PCP:

Indications
  • CD4+ T cell count <200/uL ( CD4 cell %<15)
  • Recent oropharyngeal candidiasis and prior PCP
  • Any patient with unexplained fever for > 2 weeks.
Drug of choice

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX), one double-strength tablet daily. 

Alternatives- Dapsone/Pyrimethamine + Leucovorin or Atovaqone or Aerosolised Pentamidine

Note : TMP-SMX also provides protection against toxoplasmosis and some bacterial respiratory pathogens. The prophylaxis is discontinued in those patients treated with ART who maintain good suppression of HIV (<50 copies/mL) and CD4+ T-cell counts >200/ μL for at least 3 months.

questions.text: You suffer a bleeding puncture wound on your finger while assisting with surgery on a patient infected with HIV. What regimen should you take in this situation?
questions.solution:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three-drug regimen that includes lamivudine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir.

A regimen for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
